title: Lake Taylor High graduate JJ Quinerly of West Virginia gains AP All - America honorable mention
body_text:
COLLEGE WOMEN’S BASKETBALL
Lake Taylor graduate gains AP award
West Virginia guard and former Lake Taylor High star JJ Quinerly received Associated Press All-America honorable mention.
She was named first-team All-Big 12 and was the conference’s Defensive Player of the Year. Quinerly leads the Mountaineers in scoring (19.6 points per game) and steals (2.9 per game).
She also is a semifinalist for the Naismith Defensive Player of the Year and is on the WBCA Player of the Year Watchlist. Her team will face Princeton in the NCAA Tournament, and a victory likely would mean a chance against Iowa and megastar Caitlin Clark.
FOOTBALL
NSU/HU Pro Day relocated to ODU
Pro Day for Norfolk State and Hampton, originally scheduled for Friday afternoon at Dick Price Stadium, was relocated. The Spartans and Pirates instead will instead participate in Old Dominion’s Pro Day on Friday morning.
SUN BELT CONFERENCE
JMU leads Bubas Cup standings
Thanks to conference championships in women’s swimming and diving as well as men’s basketball and a top-four finish in women’s basketball, James Madison leads the Sun Belt’s Vic Bubas Cup standings, which recognizes the top athletics department in the conference based on a point system
JMU has 87.5 points, ahead of second-place Arkansas State (74), Appalachian State (72) and Marshall (70.5). Old Dominion (31.5) is tied for eighth with Georgia Southern.
COLLEGE SOFTBALL
N.C. Central wins pair at Norfolk State
North Carolina Central swept host Norfolk State 3-0, 5-3.
In Game 1, the Eagles’ Jaden Davis pitched a four-hit shutout, and Hailey Batista’s two-run homer in the second inning proved decisive. Rylie Gilbreath was 2 for 3 for the Spartans (2-28, 1-4 MEAC), and Brierra Tyler took the loss despite striking out eight in a complete game.
N.C. Central (7-21, 3-2) took a 3-0 lead off losing pitcher Emma Zieg in Game 2 before the Spartans’ Emree Sky Obispo drew a bases-loaded walk and Kira Turner hit an RBI groundout in the second inning.
Gilbreath had three hits in Game 2, including an RBI single in the sixth. But Davis pitched 5 2/3 innings for the victory, and teammate Jaylah Barr was 3 for 4 with a run and an RBI.
COLLEGE WRESTLING
Hokies’ Lewis to wrestle three-time champ in quarterfinals
Carter Starocci of Penn State rolled into the quarterfinals at the NCAA championships in Kansas City, Missouri, but now the three-time champ will have to face the top seed at 174 pounds.
Starocci was given a surprising No. 9 seed after injury defaults at the Big Ten championships, so he will be wrestling No. 1 seed Mekhi Lewis of Virginia Tech, a four-time ACC champion and former NCAA champ at 165, much earlier than he might have otherwise.
Starocci was part of another dominant day for the two-time defending champion Nittany Lions, who still have eight wrestlers chasing national titles. Among them is Aaron Brooks at 197 pounds, where he is trying to win his fourth championship.
Penn State had 34.5 points while Iowa and Iowa State were tied for second at 24.5 points.
Lewis and three fellow Hokies advanced to the quarterfinals: Caleb Henson, Bryce Andonian and Thomas Stewart Jr. Quarterfinal winners will secure All-American status.
At 149, fourth-seeded Henson meets No. 5 Ty Watters of West Virginia. At 157, 12th-seeded Andonian faces No. 4 Ed Scott of N.C. State. At 184, seventh-seeded Stewart meets No. 2 Isaiah Salazar of Minnesota.
Five other Hokies lost Thursday and are in the consolation brackets: Cooper Flynn (125), Sam Latona (133), Tom Crook (141), Andy Smith (197) and Hunter Catka (285).
COLLEGE WOMEN’S GOLF
Great Bridge alumna gains Sun Belt award
Great Bridge High graduate Kendall Turner, a James Madison redshirt senior, was named the Sun Belt Golfer of the Week.
The Chesapeake native finished fourth among 81 golfers at the Western Kentucky Spring Break Shootout, propelling the Dukes to third place among 15 competing teams. Her 6-under-par 207 provided her 18th top-10 finish for JMU.
WOMEN’S SWIMMING AND DIVING
UVA excelling early with NCAA lead
Gretchen Walsh broke her own collegiate, American and U.S. Open record in the 50-yard freestyle and her sister Alex Walsh took the 200 individual medley to help Virginia move into first on the team leaderboard in the NCAA women’s swimming and diving championships in Athens, Georgia.
Jasmine Nocentini and Maxine Parker joined the Walsh sisters to win the 200-yard freestyle relay with a time of 1:24.05, an NCAA championship record. Gretchen Walsh won the 50 freestyle in 20.37, breaking her own mark of 20.41 set in the preliminaries.
Nocentini took third with a personal-best time of 21.10. Alex Walsh had a personal-best time of 1:49.20 to set a pool record at the Jack Bauerle Pool at Gabrielsen Natatorium. She also won the event at the 2021 and 2022 championships.
Virginia opened the meet by winning the 200 medley relay and placing fourth in the 800 freestyle relay. Wednesday night.
Gretchen Walsh, Nocentini, Carly Novelline and Parker posted a first-place time of 1:31.58, just shy of the NCAA record of 1:31.51 set by the Cavaliers last year. Aimee Canny, Alex Walsh, Ella Nelson, and junior Reilly Tiltmann finished fourth in a program-record 6:51.41, snapping UVA’s NCAA-relay winning streak at nine races.
COLLEGE HONORS
JMU’s Bourne earns national recognition
James Madison athletic director Jeff Bourne has earned two national honors this week. He was one of four FBS AD of the Year honorees selected by the National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics, and he was one of five nominees for the Sports Business Journal College AD of the Year Award.
COLLEGE MEN’S TENNIS
N.C. A&T edges Norfolk State
Norfolk State (5-7) lost 4-3 to North Carolina A&T. Of the Spartans’ last four defeats, all were 4-3.
Boris Lunin and Fred McRae won in singles for the Spartans, who had gone ahead 1-0 by winning two doubles sets.
